1.name: Dāna
1.shortDescription: The practice of giving and opening without expectation of return.
1.fullDescription: Dāna is the willingness to give and open without religious or pious motives, simply doing what is required in any moment. It is learning to trust in your fundamental richness, realizing you do not need to constantly secure your ground. This perfection involves a surrendering process where you give up your psychological 'demand' and the basic criteria of that demand. Generosity is also a form of communication that must transcend irritation and self-defensiveness to be truly open and naked.
1.story: The Buddha once taught his followers to release their 'cows'—the things we think are essential for our existence but are actually obstacles to our happiness. He told a story of a farmer who was distraught because his twelve cows ran away and his crops were eaten by insects. The Buddha noted that he and his monks were happy people because they had no cows to lose, illustrating that true generosity and non-attachment lead to immense freedom.

quote.text: The gift of Truth excels all other gifts.
quote.author: Buddha

practices.title: Give your true presence
practices.description: Breathe mindfully to bring your body and mind together so you can tell a loved one, 'Darling, I am here for you.' This is the greatest gift you can offer.

practices.title: Offer space
practices.description: Recognize that like a flower arrangement, people need space to radiate beauty. Practice giving the people you love more psychological and physical space.

practices.title: Flower watering
practices.description: Practice 'flower watering' by verbally recognizing and praising a positive quality in someone today. This helps their wholesome seeds to grow.

2.name: Sīla
2.shortDescription: Living in harmony with the unity of life through ethical conduct.
2.fullDescription: Sīla is not a matter of binding oneself to rigid laws or patterns, but acting according to openness. If a person is completely selfless, they will naturally fall into patterns of correct action without needing premeditated rules. It focuses on Right Speech, Right Action, and Right Livelihood, aiming to promote a happy and harmonious life for both the individual and society. It is the indispensable foundation for all higher spiritual attainments.
2.story: When the Buddha and Ananda found a monk suffering from dysentery who had been neglected by others, they bathed him and cleaned his room. The Buddha then told the other monks, 'If we do not look after each other, who will look after us? When you look after each other, you are looking after the Tathagata'.

quote.text: By oneself indeed is evil done and by oneself is one defiled... Purity and impurity depend on oneself.
quote.author: Buddha

practices.title: Abstain from gossip
practices.description: Practice Right Speech by refraining from talk that may bring about hatred, disunity, or disharmony among others.

practices.title: Protect the environment
practices.description: Practice Right Action by choosing to live simply and avoiding the exploitation of nature and other living beings.

practices.title: Mindful consumption
practices.description: Observe the Fifth Mindfulness Training by consuming only items that preserve peace and well-being in your body and mind.

3.name: Nekkhamma
3.shortDescription: The freedom found in letting go of craving and worldly attachments.
3.fullDescription: Renunciation is not an escape from life, but a way to relate to reality without being enslaved by the 'horse' of habit energy. It involves seeing that worldly pleasures are like a 'borrowed fancy carriage'—eventually, the owners (time and change) will take them back, leaving the un-renounced person dejected. True renunciation is 'swimming against the current' of race-old urges and self-centered conditioning to find an island where there is no clinging. It is the practice of emptying your boat so that it can travel faster toward liberation.
3.story: At age 29, Prince Siddhartha looked upon his sleeping wife and son one last time and slipped away in the dark hours before dawn. He traded his royal robes for the saffron rags of a convict to signify that he was no longer a captive of his own palace but a seeker of the unconditioned.

quote.text: Choose the path that leads to nirvana; avoid the road to profit and pleasure.
quote.author: Buddha

practices.title: Identify your 'cows'
practices.description: Identify one thing you think you 'must' have to be happy (a 'cow'). Practice going without it for 24 hours to realize you can be happy without owning it.

practices.title: Empty your boat
practices.description: Cast out the heavy burdens of greed and hatred that weigh down your life. Let go of one possession or grudge today.

practices.title: Release spiritual materialism
practices.description: Abandon the tendency to collect spiritual paths or knowledge to build up your pride. Practice the teachings simply, without ego.

4.name: Paññā
4.shortDescription: The ability to see through concepts and perceive things as they truly are.
4.fullDescription: Paññā is the 'all-seeing eye' and a sharp sword that cuts through all concepts. It is the ability to see situations as they are, without the interference of the ego's 'watcher'. It transforms primitive preconceptions and allows one to see the interdependent and impermanent nature of all phenomena. True wisdom means being 'suspended nowhere,' not distinguishing between 'this' and 'that'.
4.story: The Buddha told of a king who gathered blind men to touch an elephant. One touched the trunk and said an elephant is like a plow pole; another touched the ear and said it is like a winnowing basket. They fought because they each clung to a partial view. Wisdom is the panoramic view from above that sees the whole elephant.

quote.text: The light of wisdom is supreme.
quote.author: Buddha

practices.title: Are you sure?
practices.description: Write 'Are you sure?' on a piece of paper and keep it visible. Ask this of your perceptions several times today to avoid falling into wrong views.

practices.title: The Flower and the Universe
practices.description: Look at a flower and try to see the 'non-flower elements' in it: the sunshine, the clouds, the soil, and the gardener. Realize it cannot exist by itself alone.

practices.title: Contemplate impermanence
practices.description: Reflect on how everything is in a state of flux. Notice the changing nature of your thoughts, feelings, and the world around you.

5.name: Viriya
5.shortDescription: Joyous energy that leads us into situations without missing opportunities.
5.fullDescription: Viriya is energy born of joy and intense interest in the creative patterns of life. It is not the kind of energy used to work hard because one feels they 'must,' but rather a quality of delight in involvement. It involves the 'Fourfold Right Diligence': preventing unwholesome seeds from arising, helping those that have arisen to subside, and helping wholesome seeds to arise and grow. It is the energy that makes one truly alive, with shining eyes and solid steps.
5.story: The Buddha once asked the monk Sona, a former musician, what happens if the strings of his vina are too tight or too loose. Sona replied that they either break or produce no sound. The Buddha taught that Right Diligence is the same: one must maintain health and joy without forcing oneself beyond their limits.

quote.text: The wise man protects his diligence as a supreme treasure.
quote.author: Buddha

practices.title: Selective Watering
practices.description: Identify a positive quality (seed) in yourself or a loved one and find a way to 'water' it through praise or attention today.

practices.title: Changing the Peg
practices.description: When an unwholesome thought arises, replace it with a wholesome one, just as a carpenter replaces a rotten peg by driving in a new one.

practices.title: Prevent unwholesome seeds
practices.description: Be mindful throughout the day to prevent unwholesome seeds like anger, jealousy, or greed from arising in your mind consciousness.

6.name: Khanti
6.shortDescription: The capacity to receive, embrace, and transform pain without fighting it.
6.fullDescription: Khanti is the 'soft and noble heart' that allows for a communication process that is warm and penetrable. It is not merely about trying to be a hard worker or a forebearing person, but about having no expectation or impatience. It requires an awareness of the 'space' between oneself and a situation, ensuring one is never shocked or disturbed by destructive or chaotic events. True inclusiveness means your heart is as large as a river, capable of receiving a handful of salt without becoming undrinkable.
6.story: Shariputra once delivered a 'Lion's Roar' of inclusiveness when falsely accused of being rude to a fellow monk. He explained that he practiced to be like the earth, which receives both fragrant flowers and foul excrement equally, without grasping or aversion, using its power to receive, embrace, and transform all things.

quote.text: Hatred is never appeased by hatred in this world; it is appeased by love. This is an eternal Law.
quote.author: Buddha

practices.title: Identify the 'second arrow'
practices.description: When you experience physical or emotional pain, recognize it as the first arrow. Avoid the 'second arrow'—the fear, hatred, or anger that amplifies the initial pain.

practices.title: The Gift of Reconciliation
practices.description: If you are angry at someone, prepare a small gift for them. When you feel ready, offer it to them to break the cycle of suffering.

practices.title: Be like the Earth
practices.description: Practice receiving all experiences—both pleasant and unpleasant—like the earth receives fragrant flowers and foul waste without aversion or grasping.

7.name: Sacca
7.shortDescription: Loyalty to the truth in thought, word, and deed.
7.fullDescription: Truthfulness is the foundation of honesty and integrity (Ajjava). It requires not only abstaining from lies and exaggerations but also speaking in a way that is beneficial and timely. A wise person who protects the truth states their beliefs as 'this is my faith' without falling into the dogmatic trap of saying 'only this is true and everything else is false'. Words are powerful weapons; truthfulness ensures they are used to heal and reconcile rather than to divide or destroy.
7.story: When the Buddha returned to his home city, his father King Shuddhodana was angry that his son had become a beggar. The Buddha truthfully replied that he was not a king of a small territory through power, but a ruler of the whole world through love, having brought a treasure (the Dharma) that no other son could provide.

quote.text: One who transgresses the central law of life, who speaks falsely... is capable of any evil.
quote.author: Buddha

practices.title: The 'Are you sure?' test
practices.description: Before speaking or acting on a perception, ask yourself 'Am I sure?'. This prevents you from projecting your own biases as absolute truths.

practices.title: Noble Silence
practices.description: If what you are about to say is true but not useful or kind, practice 'thundering silence'.

practices.title: Call things by their true names
practices.description: Speak truthfully by naming your emotions and experiences accurately (e.g., 'depression,' 'anger') without minimizing or exaggerating.

8.name: Adhiṭṭhāna
8.shortDescription: Unwavering determination to follow the path regardless of obstacles.
8.fullDescription: Determination is the energy of a 'brave warrior' who trusts in their potential to complete the spiritual journey. It is a one-pointedness of mind that prevents one from being blown from side to side by the storms of emotion. This perfection requires 'unflinching determination' and a focus on 'nowness'—working with the present state of mind rather than dreaming of future attainments. It is the bridge that carries us through disappointment and failure until the goal is won.
8.story: Near the city of Gaya, Siddhartha seated himself beneath a tree and made a solemn vow: 'Come what may—let my body rot, let my bones be reduced to ashes—I will not get up from here until I have found the way'. Despite the attacks of Mara's armies, he sat like a mountain unshaken by an earthquake until dawn.

quote.text: Guard your mind against negative thoughts. Pull yourself out of bad ways as an elephant raises itself out of the mud.
quote.author: Buddha

practices.title: Just Sitting
practices.description: Commit to sitting for 10 minutes without moving or yielding to the urge to scratch or shift. Observe the impulses but do not act on them.

practices.title: Make your mind a fortress
practices.description: Resolve to protect your mind from negative thoughts and influences. Conquer doubt and distraction with wisdom.

practices.title: Commit to the present
practices.description: Fix your practice on 'nowness'—work with your present state of mind rather than dreaming of future spiritual attainments.

9.name: Mettā
9.shortDescription: The capacity to offer joy and friendship to all beings without discrimination.
9.fullDescription: Mettā is the intention to offer joy and happiness. It is not a sentimental feeling but a 'limitless heart' that pervades the world like a mother's love for her only child. True loving-kindness is unconditional; it does not expect anything in return and does not exclude those who have done us harm. It is the practice of 'selective watering'—refusing to water seeds of anger and instead watering the seeds of joy in ourselves and others.
9.story: The Buddha taught that hatred is never appeased by hatred, but by love alone. He illustrated this through the 'Simile of the Saw,' saying that even if bandits were to saw off your limbs, if you gave rise to a mind of hate toward them, you would not be carrying out his teaching.

quote.text: The disciples of Gautama are wide awake and vigilant, rejoicing in compassion day and night.
quote.author: Buddha

practices.title: Flower Watering
practices.description: Practice 'flower watering' by verbally recognizing and praising a positive quality in someone today. This helps their wholesome seeds to grow.

practices.title: The First Ray
practices.description: Upon waking, smile and vow: 'I vow to live fully in each moment and to look at all beings with eyes of compassion'.

practices.title: Love like a mother
practices.description: Love the world as a mother loves her only child—with boundless, protective, unconditional care that does not discriminate.

10.name: Upekkhā
10.shortDescription: Stability of mind that is not shaken by the ups and downs of life.
10.fullDescription: Equanimity is the 'wisdom of equality' that removes the boundaries between self and other. It allows a person to face life's eight worldly conditions—gain and loss, fame and disrepute, praise and blame, pleasure and pain—without being elated or dejected. It is like a solid rock that cannot be moved by the wind. Equanimity is not indifference; it is a state of being master of the situation, allowing life to flow around and through you without leaving a knot of attachment.
10.story: The Buddha described the wise as being like a flame that burns through the night: the flame is not the same from moment to moment, yet it continues without being a 'permanent' thing. By realizing that we are like waves that are actually water, we lose the fear of rising and falling, which is the heart of equanimity.

quote.text: The victor breeds hatred, and the defeated lies down in misery. He who renounces both victory and defeat is happy and peaceful.
quote.author: Buddha

practices.title: The Mirror Practice
practices.description: Visualize your 'enemy' and practice seeing them as another version of yourself, sharing the same human desire for happiness and fear of pain.

practices.title: Practice letting be
practices.description: Feel energy patterns in your body and mind without trying to subdue, change, or control them. Simply observe with non-attachment.

practices.title: Face the eight conditions
practices.description: When you experience gain or loss, praise or blame, pleasure or pain today, maintain a rock-like stability of mind.

practices.title: Mindful breathing presence
practices.description: Produce your true presence for a loved one by practicing mindful breathing before you meet.

practices.title: Selective touching
practices.description: Practice 'selective touching' by watering the wholesome seeds of others through sincere praise and recognition.

practices.title: Offer freshness
practices.description: Breathe mindfully and see yourself as a flower offering freshness and beauty to those around you.

practices.title: Give space to radiate
practices.description: Give others space to radiate their own beauty, like flowers in a well-arranged bouquet.

practices.title: Send a reconciliation gift
practices.description: Send a small gift to someone you are angry with to break the cycle of suffering and resentment.

practices.title: Offer understanding
practices.description: Look deeply into the needs, fears, and aspirations of another person and offer them genuine understanding.

practices.title: Practice flower watering
practices.description: Verbally recognize and praise the positive qualities you see in those around you today.

practices.title: Share material resources
practices.description: Share food, clothing, or other material resources with someone in real need.

practices.title: Abstain from stinginess
practices.description: Share your very last morsel of food if someone in need is present, overcoming all traces of niggardliness.

practices.title: Support the community
practices.description: Make an offering of food, time, or service to your spiritual community or sangha.

practices.title: Practice the Five Great Gifts
practices.description: Strictly observe the five mindfulness trainings as a gift of safety and non-fear to all beings.

practices.title: Give non-fear
practices.description: Touch the 'ultimate dimension' of no-birth and no-death, and share this gift of fearlessness with others.

practices.title: Care for your parents
practices.description: Minister to your parents by supporting them emotionally, physically, or financially in their old age.

practices.title: Offer inspiring speech
practices.description: Speak words that inspire self-confidence, joy, and hope in those who hear you.

practices.title: Give without expectation
practices.description: Give something of value today without expecting a reward, gratitude, or specific result.

practices.title: Give respectfully
practices.description: When giving to anyone, look at them with appreciation and respect, not with pity or superiority.

practices.title: Share the Dharma
practices.description: Share a teaching or insight from the Dharma with someone who is ready and open to hear it.

practices.title: Offer your stability
practices.description: Contemplate a mountain and embody its solidity, then remain stable and present for someone in crisis.

practices.title: Relinquish 'me' and 'mine'
practices.description: Let go of internal attachments to the notions of 'me' and 'mine' when sharing with others.

practices.title: Build mindful community
practices.description: Help build or support a community that dwells in mindfulness, compassion, and peace.

practices.title: Abstain from destroying life
practices.description: Protect all forms of life today, from insects to animals to plants, avoiding any unnecessary harm.

practices.title: Practice mere recognition
practices.description: Simply identify your body's movements as they happen—walking, sitting, standing—without judgment.

practices.title: Mindful consumption
practices.description: Consume only items (food, media, entertainment) that preserve peace and well-being in body and mind.

practices.title: Practice Right Livelihood
practices.description: Examine your work and abstain from trades involving weapons, intoxicants, poisons, or exploitation.

practices.title: Telephone meditation
practices.description: Before answering the phone, take three mindful breaths to center yourself and be fully present.

practices.title: Practice mouth yoga
practices.description: Smile gently throughout the day to relax your facial muscles and cultivate inner joy.

practices.title: Acknowledge habit energies
practices.description: When you notice a habit energy arising, smile to it with awareness rather than letting it control you.

practices.title: Abstain from sexual misconduct
practices.description: Protect the integrity and happiness of families by maintaining sexual ethics and fidelity.

practices.title: Don't take what's not given
practices.description: Refrain from taking anything—material or immaterial—that is not freely offered to you.

practices.title: Guard the sense doors
practices.description: When seeing, hearing, or sensing, don't grasp at pleasant objects or push away unpleasant ones.

practices.title: Practice Right Action
practices.description: Be nonviolent in every deed, from how you walk to how you interact with others.

practices.title: Adopt Right Speech
practices.description: Ensure your speech is timely, true, gentle, and beneficial before you speak.

practices.title: Sacred family duties
practices.description: Perform your duties toward family members as a form of sacred worship and loving service.

practices.title: Observe Uposatha
practices.description: On the full moon or new moon, observe the eight precepts for a day of deeper practice.

practices.title: Be a lamp unto yourself
practices.description: Rely on your own virtue and wisdom as a refuge, rather than external authorities or rituals.

practices.title: Abandon divisive speech
practices.description: Refrain from malicious speech, gossip, or words that create division between people.

practices.title: Practice Beginning Anew
practices.description: Reconcile with someone you have wronged by acknowledging your mistakes and starting fresh.

practices.title: Avoid harsh language
practices.description: Even when provoked or angry, abstain from harsh, abusive, or cruel language.

practices.title: Practice business ethics
practices.description: Abstain from deceiving, defrauding, or exploiting others in your business dealings.

practices.title: Right Mindfulness in routine
practices.description: Stay mindfully present in every routine task, from brushing teeth to washing dishes.

practices.title: Empty your boat
practices.description: Cast out the heavy burdens of greed, hatred, and delusion to lighten your life's journey.

practices.title: Release your 'cows'
practices.description: Identify the objects, people, or ideas you think you need for happiness and practice releasing attachment to them.

practices.title: Step out of ego bureaucracy
practices.description: Notice when your ego is constantly demanding more status, validation, or security—and step out of that pattern.

practices.title: Abandon spiritual materialism
practices.description: Stop collecting spiritual paths, teachings, or credentials to build up your spiritual ego.

practices.title: Practice the Hard Way
practices.description: March directly into disappointment or difficulty rather than seeking a soft landing or escape route.

practices.title: Relinquish 'I am'
practices.description: Let go of the conceit 'I am' by seeing through the illusion of a permanent, separate self.

practices.title: Rely on personal effort
practices.description: Abandon the search for external saviors or gurus to rescue you, and rely on your own effort.

practices.title: Give up the watcher
practices.description: Release the paranoid self-observation and internal 'watcher' that creates duality and separation.

practices.title: Abandon identity view
practices.description: Stop seeing the self as identical to the body, feelings, perceptions, or consciousness.

practices.title: Throw away the raft
practices.description: Once you've crossed the river of suffering, let go of the teachings and methods that got you there.

practices.title: Give away your inheritance
practices.description: Use your wealth and possessions for charity now rather than hoarding them for unloved heirs.

practices.title: Stop seeking sense pleasures
practices.description: Renounce the pursuit of sensory delights that promise temporary pleasure but lead to future pain.

practices.title: Abandon cunning solutions
practices.description: Give up the clever mental suggestions and fabrications that keep you from seeing reality clearly.

practices.title: Relinquish views
practices.description: Let go of attachment to dogmatic opinions and fixed views about how things 'should' be.

practices.title: Disown practice results
practices.description: Practice without seeking specific outcomes or spiritual attainments; let it be spontaneous.

practices.title: Relinquish desire for fame
practices.description: Let go of the craving for recognition, reputation, and renown in your spiritual or worldly life.

practices.title: Cease future planning
practices.description: Stop planning obsessively for a future self and instead dwell fully in the present moment.

practices.title: Abandon doctrine of self
practices.description: Relinquish clinging to any doctrine or belief in a permanent, unchanging self.

practices.title: Stop chasing goals
practices.description: Cease running after imaginary spiritual goals or a 'higher' version of yourself that doesn't exist.

practices.title: Renounce worldly bondage
practices.description: Stop trying to possess people, experiences, or things as 'yours'—practice non-possessiveness.

practices.title: Reflect on interdependence
practices.description: Contemplate 'Interdependent Co-Arising'—see that nothing can exist by itself alone, everything depends on everything else.

practices.title: Apply the Four Noble Truths
practices.description: Identify a specific suffering you're experiencing and apply the Four Noble Truths to understand and address it.

practices.title: Contemplate impermanence
practices.description: Reflect deeply on how everything—thoughts, emotions, objects, relationships—is in constant flux.

practices.title: Question your certainty
practices.description: Throughout the day, ask yourself 'Are you sure?' to challenge your perceptions and assumptions.

practices.title: Reflect on nonself
practices.description: Look at any object or person and try to see the 'non-flower' elements—all the conditions that make it possible.

practices.title: Practice Right View
practices.description: Observe your mind and recognize which mental seeds are wholesome and which are unwholesome.

practices.title: Contemplate Three Dharma Seals
practices.description: Meditate on impermanence, non-self, and nirvana as the three marks of all existence.

practices.title: Contemplate the Eight No's
practices.description: Reflect on the teaching of no birth, no death, no coming, no going, no same, no different, no being, no non-being.

practices.title: Analyze your nutriments
practices.description: Observe how your consumption of food, sensory impressions, intentions, and consciousness affects your well-being.

practices.title: Study the Five Aggregates
practices.description: Examine the five aggregates (form, feeling, perception, mental formations, consciousness) and see their empty nature.

practices.title: Observe rise and fall
practices.description: Watch the arising and passing away of every thought, feeling, and sensation throughout the day.

practices.title: Discern formations
practices.description: See all conditioned things (sankhara) as impermanent constructions rather than solid realities.

practices.title: Realize emptiness
practices.description: Contemplate emptiness as the middle way between the extremes of existence and non-existence.

practices.title: Apply four-truth pattern
practices.description: For any problem you face, identify it clearly, find its root cause, envision its cessation, and follow the path to that end.

practices.title: Penetrate 18 Elements
practices.description: Examine the six sense organs, six sense objects, and six types of consciousness that make up experience.

practices.title: Use wisdom as a knife
practices.description: Apply discriminating wisdom like a butcher's knife to cut through mental defilements and confusion.

practices.title: Acknowledge the unconditioned
practices.description: Touch the dimension of reality that is unconditioned, unborn, and unchanging—beyond all concepts.

practices.title: Go beyond dualism
practices.description: Practice seeing beyond dualistic notions of good versus bad, right versus wrong, self versus other.

practices.title: Investigate shunyata
practices.description: Meditate on 'nothingness' (shunyata) to remove the conceptual padding that obscures reality.

practices.title: Master Twelve Links
practices.description: Study and contemplate the Twelve Links of Dependent Origination to understand the cycle of rebirth and suffering.

practices.title: Rouse unflinching determination
practices.description: Commit to staying with your meditation or practice no matter what distractions or discomfort arise.

practices.title: Prevent unwholesome seeds
practices.description: Be vigilant throughout the day to prevent unwholesome mental seeds from arising in your consciousness.

practices.title: Return unwholesome seeds
practices.description: When unwholesome seeds like anger or jealousy arise, help them return to your storehouse consciousness without acting on them.

practices.title: Water dormant wholesome seeds
practices.description: Identify wholesome qualities that haven't manifested yet and find ways to water and cultivate them.

practices.title: Nourish active wholesome seeds
practices.description: When wholesome mental states arise (joy, compassion, gratitude), nourish them so they remain and grow stronger.

practices.title: Tune your vina
practices.description: Maintain your spiritual effort like tuning an instrument—neither too tight (forcing) nor too loose (lazy).

practices.title: Advance like a racehorse
practices.description: Break free from the habits and conditioning of the world with swift, joyful energy.

practices.title: Practice four right efforts
practices.description: Apply the fourfold right diligence to every thought: prevent unwholesome, abandon arisen unwholesome, cultivate wholesome, maintain wholesome.

practices.title: Practice Right Thought
practices.description: Resolve to think only thoughts of renunciation, loving-kindness, and harmlessness.

practices.title: Walk with elephant steps
practices.description: Move through life with the slow, sure, deliberate steps of an elephant—steady and unshakeable.

practices.title: Polish the tile
practices.description: Polish the 'tile' of your mind with joyful, continuous effort, knowing that effort itself is enlightenment.

practices.title: Cultivate joyous energy
practices.description: Take genuine interest and delight in your life exactly as it is, generating energy from that joy.

practices.title: Refuse Mara's distractions
practices.description: When faced with lust, doubt, restlessness, or other 'armies of Mara', stand firm and refuse to be distracted.

practices.title: Practice Right Diligence
practices.description: Apply sustained effort to your practice without forcing yourself or creating unnecessary suffering.

practices.title: Commit to just sitting
practices.description: Sit in meditation with absolute presence and commitment, not seeking anything or going anywhere.

practices.title: Rouse energy factor
practices.description: Cultivate energy (viriya) as one of the seven factors of awakening, maintaining effort without slackening.

practices.title: Recite the First Ray
practices.description: Upon waking, recite: 'I vow to live fully in each moment and look at all beings with eyes of compassion.'

practices.title: Overcome sloth
practices.description: Find meaning and purpose in your daily service to others, using it as medicine for laziness and sloth.

practices.title: March into life-situations
practices.description: Practice the 'Hard Way' by marching directly into challenging life situations rather than avoiding them.

practices.title: Cultivate Bodhichitta
practices.description: Rouse the mind of awakening (bodhichitta)—the deep aspiration to practice for the benefit of all beings.

practices.title: Be like the Earth
practices.description: Practice receiving all experiences—fragrant flowers or foul waste—equally, without grasping or aversion.

practices.title: Be like Water
practices.description: Receive all substances and situations like water does—equally and without discrimination—then flow on.

practices.title: Be like Fire
practices.description: Burn and consume both pure and impure experiences like fire does, without attachment or aversion.

practices.title: Be like Air
practices.description: Carry all smells, feelings, and sensations like air does—remaining spacious and empty.

practices.title: Large river heart
practices.description: Make your heart so large, like a great river, that a handful of salt cannot make the water undrinkable.

practices.title: Endure like an elephant
practices.description: When receiving harsh words or criticism, endure them like an elephant bears arrows in battle.

practices.title: Receive without crushing
practices.description: Receive suffering or injustice fully without being crushed by it—hold it with spacious awareness.

practices.title: Practice Beginning Anew
practices.description: After any disagreement or conflict, practice the ceremony of Beginning Anew to reconcile and start fresh.

practices.title: Restrain unwholesome courses
practices.description: Patiently admonish and restrain yourself from following unwholesome impulses without harsh self-judgment.

practices.title: Refuse to punish
practices.description: Consciously choose not to punish or seek revenge against those who have caused you to suffer.

practices.title: Simile of the Saw
practices.description: Even if someone were to physically harm you, maintain compassion and loving-kindness toward them.

practices.title: Embrace anger mindfully
practices.description: When anger arises, embrace it with mindfulness like a mother holding a crying baby—tenderly and without judgment.

practices.title: Practice impartiality
practices.description: In any conflict, see both sides as part of a whole rather than taking sides or making enemies.

practices.title: Avoid the second arrow
practices.description: When experiencing physical pain, don't add the 'second arrow' of mental distress, fear, or resistance.

practices.title: Practice humility
practices.description: Cultivate humility to transform your internal knots of pride, anger, and resentment.

practices.title: Face eight worldly conditions
practices.description: Maintain equanimity when facing gain or loss, fame or disrepute, praise or blame, pleasure or pain.

practices.title: See enemy as victim
practices.description: Recognize that your 'enemy' is a victim of their own wrong perceptions and suffering, not inherently evil.

practices.title: Unshaken by praise or blame
practices.description: Don't be elated by praise or dejected by blame—remain steady like a rock in the wind.

practices.title: Wait for seeds to ripen
practices.description: Patiently wait for your spiritual seeds and efforts to ripen at their own natural pace.

practices.title: Peace with your ailments
practices.description: Practice inclusiveness even with your own physical or mental ailments, living in peace with them.

practices.title: Call things by true names
practices.description: Speak truthfully by naming emotions and experiences accurately (e.g., 'depression,' 'anger') without minimizing or exaggerating.

practices.title: Avoid forked tongue
practices.description: Don't speak with a 'forked tongue' by varying your story for different people or audiences.

practices.title: Practice Right Speech
practices.description: Ensure your speech is timely, gentle, truthful, and beneficial before you open your mouth.

practices.title: Confess your mistakes
practices.description: Acknowledge your mistakes openly and confess them to your community or spiritual friends.

practices.title: State 'This is my faith'
practices.description: When sharing your beliefs, say 'This is my faith' rather than claiming 'This alone is truth and everything else is false.'

practices.title: Don't clinch to views
practices.description: Treat your views and opinions like a raft to be used and discarded, not clung to or carried.

practices.title: Be loyal to truth
practices.description: Maintain unwavering loyalty to the truth in every word you speak, even when it's difficult.

practices.title: Confess hypocrisy immediately
practices.description: When you notice yourself being hypocritical, confess it immediately to open your mind and heart.

practices.title: Keep your commitments
practices.description: Honor all your commitments, promises, and vows with complete integrity.

practices.title: Use sweet words for Dharma
practices.description: Share the teachings of the Dharma using kind, gentle, and sweet words that touch people's hearts.

practices.title: Avoid embellishing stories
practices.description: Refrain from exaggerating or embellishing stories to make them sound more extreme or dramatic.

practices.title: Catch unwholesome thoughts
practices.description: Use mindfulness to catch unwholesome thoughts before they become unwholesome speech.

practices.title: Be straightforward with friends
practices.description: Practice completely straightforward communication with your spiritual friends and teachers.

practices.title: Practice Right Thinking
practices.description: Ensure your speech comes from seeds of wisdom and compassion, not from habit energy or reactivity.

practices.title: Refuse untruthful policies
practices.description: Decline to support or participate in policies, practices, or systems based on untruth.

practices.title: Guard your tongue
practices.description: Guard your tongue as carefully as you would train and care for a valuable, well-trained horse.

practices.title: Abstain from idle chatter
practices.description: Avoid useless gossip, idle chatter, and meaningless talk that wastes time and energy.

practices.title: Practice thundering silence
practices.description: When words would be false, unkind, or harmful, practice 'thundering silence' instead.

practices.title: Refuse false testimony
practices.description: Never testify falsely or bend the truth for your own benefit or to harm another.

practices.title: Be straight and upright
practices.description: Be completely straight and upright in every bodily action, reflecting inner truthfulness outwardly.

practices.title: Make your mind a fortress
practices.description: Resolve to make your mind an impenetrable fortress and conquer Mara with the power of wisdom.

practices.title: Meditate until peace
practices.description: Resolve not to get up from your meditation seat until you have reached a state of deep peace.

practices.title: Vow to help all beings
practices.description: Make a sincere vow to help all beings attain the awakened state, not just yourself.

practices.title: Mind like a broken gong
practices.description: Keep your mind one-pointed and still, like a broken gong that makes no sound when struck.

practices.title: Commit to Eightfold Path
practices.description: Make a firm commitment to follow the Noble Eightfold Path as your primary direction in life.

practices.title: Focus on Dharma always
practices.description: Keep your thoughts focused on the Dharma day and night, making it the center of your life.

practices.title: Practice selective concentration
practices.description: Abandon all distractions and focus your mind single-pointedly on one meditation object.

practices.title: Sit firmly on a lotus
practices.description: Sit firmly in the present moment as if seated on a lotus flower—grounded yet pure.

practices.title: Concentration of desire
practices.description: Channel the energy of desire into intense concentration for the sake of awakening.

practices.title: Rely on Dharma as lamp
practices.description: Resolve to rely on the Dharma as your only lamp and refuge, not on external authorities.

practices.title: Sustain mental unification
practices.description: Practice sustaining mental unification through the four progressive stages of meditative absorption (jhana).

practices.title: Unshakable Triple Gem faith
practices.description: Maintain unshakeable confidence and faith in the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha.

practices.title: Be intrepid in practice
practices.description: Follow your teacher's instructions with complete courage and determination, even when they're difficult.

practices.title: Avoid veering to extremes
practices.description: Walk the middle way without veering toward extremes of luxury, comfort, pain, or self-mortification.

practices.title: Fix practice on nowness
practices.description: Anchor your practice firmly in the present moment, not in dreams of future attainment.

practices.title: Pursue the noble search
practices.description: Dedicate yourself to the 'noble search' for the unborn, the deathless, and security from bondage.

practices.title: Order life around Right Purpose
practices.description: Organize your entire life—work, relationships, leisure—around Right Intention and Right Purpose.

practices.title: Unshakeable like a mountain
practices.description: Resolve to be as unshakeable as a mountain standing firm against powerful winds and storms.

practices.title: Return to marketplace
practices.description: Resolve to 'return to the marketplace with open hands' to help others after your own realization.

practices.title: Practice vajra-like samadhi
practices.description: Cultivate diamond-like concentration (vajra samadhi) that cuts through all nonsense and mental games.

practices.title: Pervade four quarters with love
practices.description: Send thoughts of loving-kindness to all beings in the four directions—north, south, east, and west.

practices.title: Love like a mother
practices.description: Love all beings in the world as a mother loves her only child—boundlessly and without conditions.

practices.title: Maintain intention to offer joy
practices.description: Keep the constant intention to offer joy and happiness (maitri) to everyone you encounter.

practices.title: Look with compassion eyes
practices.description: Practice looking at everyone with the 'eyes of compassion', seeing them as another version of yourself.

practices.title: Wish all beings happiness
practices.description: Repeatedly wish: 'May all beings be happy, safe, secure, and free from suffering.'

practices.title: Listen to cries of suffering
practices.description: Open your heart to listen deeply to the cries and suffering of the world around you.

practices.title: Offer your presence
practices.description: Give the gift of your full, undivided presence to those who are suffering or in need.

practices.title: Water positive seeds
practices.description: Specifically 'water the positive seeds' in others by recognizing and praising their wholesome qualities.

practices.title: Develop unbound love
practices.description: Cultivate boundless love that does not discriminate between self and other, friend and stranger.

practices.title: Practice Right Thought
practices.description: Think only thoughts of renunciation, loving-kindness, and non-violence throughout the day.

practices.title: Recite 'I am here for you'
practices.description: Say to someone you love: 'Darling, I am here for you' with your full presence and sincerity.

practices.title: Recite 'I know you suffer'
practices.description: Say to someone in pain: 'Darling, I know you suffer. That is why I am here for you.'

practices.title: Speak kind words
practices.description: Speak only kind, gentle, and lovely words that go straight to people's hearts.

practices.title: Be hospitable and charitable
practices.description: Practice hospitality and generosity toward your relatives, neighbors, and community members.

practices.title: Protect family as western direction
practices.description: Protect and care for your spouse and children like guarding the 'western direction' of your life.

practices.title: Treat all as yourself
practices.description: Look at all living creatures and treat them exactly as you would treat yourself.

practices.title: Transform anger into love
practices.description: When anger arises, embrace it mindfully and transform it into loving-kindness through understanding.

practices.title: Practice Maitreya's work
practices.description: Fulfill the deep wish to bring happiness and well-being to all beings, like the future Buddha Maitreya.

practices.title: Reconcile all conflicts
practices.description: Make it your practice to reconcile and resolve all conflicts, no matter how small or insignificant.

practices.title: Be a spiritual friend
practices.description: Be a 'kalyana-mitta' (spiritual friend) to everyone on the path, supporting their practice and growth.

practices.title: Practice letting be
practices.description: Feel the energy patterns in your body and mind without trying to subdue, change, or control them.

practices.title: Unaffected by praise or blame
practices.description: Remain completely unaffected by good and bad news, praise and criticism, success and failure.

practices.title: Look with nondiscriminating wisdom
practices.description: Look over the entire world with wisdom that does not discriminate or take sides.

practices.title: Practice wisdom of equality
practices.description: See the interconnection in conflicts—see 'Israel in Palestine and Palestine in Israel'—recognizing shared humanity.

practices.title: Be like still water
practices.description: Become like perfectly still water that reflects all things exactly as they are, without distortion.

practices.title: Face gain and loss
practices.description: When experiencing gain or loss, maintain a mind as stable and unmoved as a solid rock.

practices.title: Accept teacher's role
practices.description: Accept whatever role your teacher gives you—'cold icy water' or 'hot fire'—with complete equanimity.

practices.title: Stop the watcher
practices.description: Abandon the 'watcher' principle that creates separation; clear away the fortifications of self-protection.

practices.title: Don't cling to the raft
practices.description: Once you've crossed the river of suffering, don't cling to the raft of teachings—let it go.

practices.title: See all fire as fire
practices.description: Recognize the essential nature in all manifestations—all fire is fire, regardless of the fuel it burns.

practices.title: Practice independence
practices.description: Walk side-by-side with friends and companions but don't lean on them or become dependent.

practices.title: Observe like a scientist
practices.description: Watch your own mind with the detached curiosity of a scientist, without judging what you observe.

practices.title: Practice Aimlessness
practices.description: Realize you already are what you want to become—there's nowhere to go and nothing to achieve.

practices.title: Relinquish all fetters
practices.description: Let go of all fetters, attachments, and personal ties that bind you to suffering.

practices.title: View death as a doorway
practices.description: See death not as an end but merely as a 'door into another room'—a natural transition.

practices.title: Give up value judgments
practices.description: Stop judging your meditation or spiritual practice as 'good' or 'bad'—just practice.

practices.title: Be at peace among war
practices.description: Maintain inner peace even when surrounded by conflict, violence, or chaos.

practices.title: Accept what is
practices.description: Accept reality exactly as it is without preparing for a 'soft landing' or trying to cushion the blow.

practices.title: Practice Upeksha
practices.description: Love all your 'children' (people, projects, ideas) equally without possessiveness or favoritism.

practices.title: Stand like a stone pillar
practices.description: Remain like a stone pillar that stands unbudged by powerful storms, earthquakes, or floods.
